reg:regulation.reg:title:
Park, Conservancy and
Recreation Area Regulation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this regulation, unless the context otherwise requires:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Park Act;
backcountry means an area in a park, conservancy or recreation area that is not frontcountry;
camp means to occupy a campsite, to set up a tent or other shelter or to remain overnight;
campground means one or more campsites managed by an operator or the ministry;
campsite means an area in a park, conservancy or recreation area developed by the ministry to accommodate persons who wish to camp;
Canada does not include a corporation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that is, under an enactment of Canada, an agent of Her Majesty in right of Canada,
of which the government of Canada owns, directly or indirectly, more than 50% of the issued voting shares, or

that is controlled by the government of Canada, and for the purpose of this definition a corporation is controlled by the government of Canada when a majority of the members of the corporation or of its board of directors or board of management consists of either or both of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: persons appointed as members by the Governor in Council, by a minister of the government of Canada or by an enactment of Canada;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: cycle means a device having any number of wheels that is propelled by human power and on which a person may ride;
day use area means an area in a park, conservancy or recreation area managed by an operator or the ministry for picnicking and other daytime activities;
designated long-stay campsite means a campsite in a park, conservancy or recreation area that has been designated as a campsite where a person may camp for more than 14 days in a calendar year;
dock means a structure connected to dry land and used for the purposes of mooring a vessel;
domestic animal means a vertebrate that has been domesticated;
firearm includes a rifle, shotgun, handgun, spring gun or any device that propels a projectile by means of an explosion, compressed gas or spring, but does not include a longbow or crossbow;
frontcountry means an area in a park, conservancy or recreation area within one kilometre of either side of the centreline of a park road or a highway;
group means 15 or more persons;
guide means a person who, for compensation or reward received or promised, accompanies, assists or provides a service to another person;

hunt means to shoot at, attract, search for, chase, pursue, follow after or on the trail of, stalk or lie in wait for wildlife, or to attempt to do any of those things, whether or not the wildlife is then or subsequently wounded, killed or captured,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the intention to capture the wildlife, or
while in possession of a firearm or other weapon;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: litter means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: garbage, refuse, rubbish or trash of any kind, including a container, package, bottle or can, or any part thereof, or
any abandoned or discarded article, product or item of manufacture,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include wastes of the primary processes of mining, logging, sawmilling, farming or manufacturing;
operator means a person authorized by a park use permit or resource use permit to operate facilities in any part of a park, conservancy or recreation area;
park includes any land, trail, path or waterway comprised in an order under section 6 (1) (a) to (g) of the Act;
park road means a road in a park, conservancy or recreation area that is designed and developed for the passage or parking of motor vehicles licensed under the Motor Vehicle Act;
party means up to 8 persons, of whom at least one, but no more than 4, are 16 years old or older, and who may have with them

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one recreational vehicle,
one non-recreational vehicle, or
one non-recreational vehicle and one legally towed trailer that is not a trailer primarily designed as temporary living quarters for recreational or travel use;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Province does not include a corporation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that is, under an Act, an agent of the Crown,
of which the government owns, directly or indirectly, more than 50% of the issued voting shares, or

that is controlled by the government, and for the purpose of this definition a corporation is controlled by the government when a majority of the members of the corporation or of its board of directors or board of management consists of either or both of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: persons appointed as members by the Lieutenant Governor in Council, by a minister or by an Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: recreational vehicle means a self-propelled vehicle or a trailer, primarily designed as temporary living quarters for recreational or travel use;
snowmobile means a snowmobile as defined in the Snowmobile Regulation, B.C. Reg. 65/72;
trap means to trap, snare, net or use any other device to take or capture wildlife;
vessel means a boat, canoe, kayak or other craft used, or capable of being used, for navigation on water;
waste means waste as defined in the Environmental Management Act;
wildlife means raptors, threatened species, endangered species, game or other species of vertebrates prescribed as wildlife under the Wildlife Act;
youth group means a group of 12 or more persons

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: undertaking a camping trip or day use trip organized for the group by a school, not-for-profit society or recreational centre operated by a municipality or regional district for the benefit of the members of the group who are 18 years of age or younger, and
supervised by an adult representative of the school, not-for-profit society or recreational centre.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This regulation does not apply to Class C parks.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Removal of property and restoration of area

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as otherwise provided in a park use permit or resource use permit, every person must, within the 30 day period following

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the expiry or other termination of a park use permit or resource use permit, or
receipt of a written order from a park officer,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: remove all personal property and dispose of all structures, improvements and works of any nature in a park, conservancy or recreation area and restore, repair or rehabilitate the area as nearly as possible to its natural condition, or restore, repair or rehabilitate the area to the satisfaction of the park officer issuing the order.
Subsection (1) does not apply to structures, improvements and works that are the property of the Province.

If a person fails to remove personal property or dispose of structures, improvements or works as required by subsection (1), a park officer may remove the personal property and dispose of the structures, improvements or works.
If a person fails to restore, repair or rehabilitate an area as required by subsection (1), a park officer may restore, repair or rehabilitate the area as the park officer considers necessary.
Any expense incurred by the Province under subsection (3) or (4) is a debt owing the Province by the person who failed to comply with subsection (1).
A debt incurred under this section may be retained from any security which the Province requires to be maintained by a person as a condition of a park use permit or resource use permit.

In the absence of a sufficient security under subsection (6) to extinguish a debt incurred under this section, the debt or remaining debt is recoverable at suit of the Province in any court of competent jurisdiction.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not act as a guide or offer services as a guide in a park, conservancy or recreation area without

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a valid park use permit or resource use permit issued for that purpose, and
a licence or permit to guide if required by or under the Wildlife Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not trap or take any fur bearing animal in a park, conservancy or recreation area without

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a valid park use permit or resource use permit issued for that purpose, and
a licence or permit to trap issued under the Wildlife Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 193/2005, App. A, s. 2.]

Every person who enters or is in a park, conservancy or recreation area must, at the request of a park officer or park ranger, provide information about any matter pertaining to the use or occupancy of the park, conservancy or recreation area including that person's correct name, address, destination and proposed activities and conduct in the park, conservancy or recreation area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not create or cause a deliberate or unnecessary disturbance in a park, conservancy or recreation area.

Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not, between the hours of 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. the following day, operate or permit another person to operate any device that produces sound at a level which disturbs the peace and quiet of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an occupant of another campsite, or
persons in the park, conservancy or recreation area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A park ranger may order a person who does anything contrary to this regulation to leave a park, conservancy or recreation area, or a specified portion of it, within a period of time specified by the park ranger, and every person so ordered must comply with the order and leave the park, conservancy or recreation area, or the specified portion of it, within that specified period of time.
If no period of time is specified in an order issued under subsection (1), the order is effective immediately.

The order issued under subsection (1) must specify the period of time during which the order is to remain in effect, but in no case may it remain in effect for more than 72 hours from the time the order is issued.

A park ranger may use reasonable force to remove a person from the park, conservancy or recreation area, or the specified portion of it, if that person fails to comply with an order under subsection (1).
A person who is ordered to leave the park, conservancy or recreation area is not entitled to a refund of any fee which may have been paid by the party or group of which that person is a member.
A park officer may erect a sign or other device specifying an area in which specific activities are permitted, prohibited or restricted in a park, conservancy or recreation area.
Every person must observe and obey every prohibition and restriction announced by the sign or other device erected under subsection (1).
A person must not start or maintain a fire in a park, conservancy or recreation area in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a campground,
frontcountry, or
backcountry that is less than 2 000 hectares in size,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: unless the fire is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a fireplace provided by the ministry, and
not more than 0.5 metres in diameter and 0.5 metres in height.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not use vegetation from a campground or from frontcountry to start or maintain a fire except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vegetation that is specifically provided as firewood by the ministry or an operator, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not use vegetation from backcountry to start or maintain a fire except vegetation that is dead and lying on the ground.
A person who starts or maintains a fire must extinguish the fire when that person leaves the campground, frontcountry or backcountry.
A park officer may, at any time,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibit a fire in a park, conservancy or recreation area,
extinguish a fire, or
require that a fire be contained within a device approved by the park officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, activated e-cigarette, e-cigarette and tobacco have the same meaning as in the Tobacco and Vapour Products Control Act.
A person must not smoke tobacco, hold lighted tobacco, use an e-cigarette or hold an activated e-cigarette in a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in an area as permitted by a sign or other device, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not use or operate any snow sliding device in Mount Seymour Park, Cypress Park or E.C. Manning Park unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in an area specifically designated and posted for such use, and
on a snow sliding device approved by a park officer.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A parent, guardian, custodian or person in charge of a minor must not permit the minor to do anything that is prohibited by the Act or this regulation.
A person who is a peace officer, park officer or park ranger is exempt from this regulation while acting in that capacity.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Obstruction of a park officer or park ranger
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not willfully obstruct a park officer or park ranger acting in that capacity.
Except on Bowron Lake or as authorized by a park officer, not more than 6 persons may travel together on the circuit of lakes in Bowron Lake Park.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not store, cache or leave equipment or supplies in a park, conservancy or recreation area for a period of more than 14 days in a calendar year.
A person must not store, cache or leave equipment or supplies in a campground or day use area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the campsite at which that person is registered, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not have a horse or other draught or riding animal in a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in an area or on a trail as permitted by a sign or other device, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not allow a domestic animal to enter or remain in any part of a park, conservancy or recreation area that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a beach within a campground or day use area,
a public building or structure, or
an area in which domestic animals are prohibited by a sign or other device.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to a domestic animal that is used to guide a blind person.

Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not allow a domestic animal to enter or remain in frontcountry or in backcountry that is less than 2 000 hectares in size unless the domestic animal is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: restrained by a leash not longer than 2 metres, or
confined in a container, enclosure or motor vehicle.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not allow a domestic animal in a park, conservancy or recreation area to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cause an annoyance,
injure a person,
damage property or vegetation, or
chase or molest wildlife.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not allow a domestic animal to enter or remain in Bowron Lake Park or Garibaldi Park.

A person who has a domestic animal in a park, conservancy or recreation area must dispose of excrement from that domestic animal in a manner and at a location where the excrement will not cause a public inconvenience or annoyance.
A park officer may order a person who contravenes this section to remove the domestic animal from the park, conservancy or recreation area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person who owns or is responsible for an animal must not, in a park, conservancy or recreation area, allow that animal to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: graze, browse or otherwise consume vegetation, or
roam at large.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not have an explosive or an explosive substance in a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: lawfully carried firearm ammunition, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Peace officer authority under Motor Vehicle Act
bcl:section.bcl:text: A park ranger has the powers and authority of a peace officer for the purposes of enforcement of the Motor Vehicle Act and control of traffic within a park, conservancy or recreation area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stop or park a vehicle on the travelled portion of a park road, or
stop or park a vehicle in such a manner as to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: impede the proper use of a park road,
restrict or inhibit recreational use of the park, conservancy or recreation area, or
park a vehicle in the frontcountry without payment of the vehicle parking fee required by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not, between the hours of 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. the following day, stop or park a vehicle in a campground, day use area or parking area of a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at a campsite where that person is the member of a registered party, group or youth group,
in a parking area as permitted by a sign or other device, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a vehicle is stopped or parked in contravention of subsection (1) or (2), a park officer may remove the vehicle to a place of impoundment and any costs incurred by that removal are a debt of the owner of the vehicle payable to the party that removed and impounded the vehicle, which debt must be paid before removal of the vehicle from the place of impoundment.

A park officer removing a vehicle under subsection (3) must exercise reasonable care to avoid damage to the vehicle involved, but neither the Province nor any park officer is liable or accountable to the owner for damage to the vehicle being removed arising from that removal.
A person must not use or operate a motor vehicle, motorcycle or other self-propelled vehicle in a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a park road,
in an area as permitted by a sign or other device, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to a self-propelled wheelchair or other similar conveyance used by a disabled person.
A person must not use or operate a snowmobile in a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in an area or on a trail as permitted by a sign or other device, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not ride a cycle in a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a park road,
in an area or on a trail as permitted by a sign or other device, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not have in a park, conservancy or recreation area a vehicle that displays advertising or is equipped with a public address system if that vehicle is being used to advertise, demonstrate or attract attention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the Act and this section, a person may use an aircraft to arrive at or depart from a park, conservancy or recreation area.

A person must not use an aircraft to arrive at or depart from parks or parts of parks that are set out in Column 1 of Schedule A, except as may be provided for in the same row in Column 2 of that schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Possession of firearms, bows and crossbows
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not possess a firearm, bow or crossbow in a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a firearm, bow or crossbow that is carried in a vehicle,
during an open season specified under the Wildlife Act in those parks, conservancies and recreation areas listed in Schedule B,
in Columbia Lake Park between September 10 and June 15 of the following year, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Discharge of firearms, bows and crossbows prohibited

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not discharge a firearm, bow or crossbow in a park, conservancy or recreation area except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: during an open season specified under the Wildlife Act in those parks, conservancies and recreation areas listed in Schedule B and only for the purposes of hunting, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not hunt or discharge a firearm, bow or crossbow in a park, conservancy or recreation area within 400 metres of either side of the centreline of a park road or highway.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not feed wildlife in a park, conservancy or recreation area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Seizure of hunting and fishing devices

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A park ranger may seize a firearm, bow, crossbow, fishing rod or other device used in a park, conservancy or recreation area to capture fish or wildlife if the park ranger finds that the firearm, bow, crossbow, fishing rod or other device is being used by or is in the possession of a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is in contravention of the Wildlife Act or section 28 or 29 of this regulation, or
fails upon request to exhibit a proper licence or permit issued under the Wildlife Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A firearm, bow, crossbow, fishing rod or other device that is seized under subsection (1) must be taken before a justice who, if satisfied that at the time of seizure it was being used or possessed in contravention of the Wildlife Act or section 28 or 29 of this regulation, may order it forfeited to the Crown.
Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: damage or destroy any natural resource or property in a park, conservancy or recreation area,
possess any natural resource or property of a park, conservancy or recreation area,
remove any natural resource or property from a park, conservancy or recreation area,
engage in any research or collection activity in a park, conservancy or recreation area,
remove water from a park, conservancy or recreation area for purposes other than personal consumption, or
deposit waste in a park, conservancy or recreation area or allow or cause waste to flow on or seep into any land or water or to be emitted into the air.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) (a) to (c) does not apply to wildlife taken under this regulation.
A person must not deposit litter in a park, conservancy or recreation area except in a receptacle, pit or area provided for that purpose by the ministry or an operator.
If a receptacle, pit or area is not provided for the deposit of litter, a person must not leave litter in a park, conservancy or recreation area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transporting litter into a park, conservancy or recreation area
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not bring domestic, commercial or industrial litter into a park, conservancy or recreation area for the purpose of disposal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every party, group or youth group using a park, conservancy or recreation area facility or service for which a fee is payable must designate one person to be the designated representative of that party, group or youth group.
Except as authorized by a park officer, the designated representative must be 16 years of age or older.
The designated representative must be responsible for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registration of the party, group or youth group,
the payment of fees required to be paid by that party, group or youth group under this regulation, and
the actions and conduct of each person in the party, group or youth group and each guest and visitor of that party, group or youth group while in the park, conservancy or recreation area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The designated representative of a party, group or youth group that camps or uses facilities or services of a park, conservancy or recreation area for which the minister, by regulation or directive, has established a fee, must register with the ministry or an operator, as the case may be, by providing all of the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the correct name of the designated representative;
the number of persons in the party, group or youth group;
the mode of transportation of the party, group or youth group;
any other information reasonably required to identify the party, group or youth group.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not, between the hours of 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. the following day, enter or remain in a campground except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who is the member of a registered party, group or youth group, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person must not, between the hours of 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. the following day, enter or remain in a day use area.

bcl:section.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Reg. 141/2009, Sch. ss. 1 (d) and (e) and 6.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not camp in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: frontcountry, or
backcountry less than 2 000 hectares in size

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a campsite, or
as authorized by a park officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If backcountry is 2 000 hectares or more in size, a park officer may restrict camping to a designated area, campground or campsite.
A person may not camp in a park, conservancy or recreation area for more than 14 days except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as authorized by a park officer, or
in a designated long-stay campsite.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a park officer, a person who owns a vessel or is responsible for a vessel must not allow that vessel to remain overnight in a park, conservancy or recreation area for more than 14 days in a calendar year.
A park officer may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: limit at any one time the number of persons, vehicles or vessels in a park, conservancy or recreation area or any part of a park, conservancy or recreation area, or
close to public use a park, conservancy or recreation area or any part of a park, conservancy or recreation area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Notwithstanding section 39, a park officer may limit the length of stay of a person in a park, conservancy or recreation area.
A party may not have more than one recreational vehicle on a campsite.
A party may have a second non-recreational vehicle on a campsite

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if so authorized by a park officer and on payment of the fee established by regulation or directive of the minister, or
if the campsite is a designated long-stay campsite.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Maximum number of persons on a campsite
bcl:section.bcl:text: No more than 8 persons may occupy a campsite, unless a park officer authorizes a different number.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If fees established by the minister by regulation or directive are levied on an overnight basis, the overnight period commences at 12 noon and terminates at 12 noon the following day.

If fees established by the minister by regulation or directive are levied on a day basis, the day period commences and terminates at the times approved by a park officer between 7 a.m. and 11 p.m. on the same day.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The designated representative of a party, group or youth group that camps or uses a campsite or other authorized facility or area in a park, conservancy or recreation area must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of a campsite or other authorized facility or area managed by the minister, pay to the ministry the fees established by regulation or directive of the minister, or
in respect of a campsite or other authorized facility or area managed by an operator, pay to the operator the fees established by regulation or directive of the minister.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 67/94, s. 3.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 141/2009, Sch. s. 11.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Park use permit and resource use permit fees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person applying for a park use permit or resource use permit for a purpose listed in Schedule K, Part 1, Column 1, must pay to the minister the application fee set out opposite that purpose in Column 2.
A permit holder must, for a request or requirement listed in Schedule K, Part 2, Column 1, pay to the minister the fee set out in Column 2 opposite that request or requirement.
A person to whom a permit listed in Schedule K, Part 3, Column 1 was issued before January 30, 2018 must pay to the minister the fee set out opposite that permit type in Column 2

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a permit issued for a term of one year or less, when the permit is issued, and
in the case of a permit issued for a term of more than one year, when the permit is issued and, annually thereafter, before the anniversary date of the issue of the permit, until the end of the term.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No fee is payable under this section for a park use permit or resource use permit issued

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to British Columbia or to Canada,
for the purposes of research,
for public telephones,
for the operation of campground and day facilities in a park, conservancy or recreation area,

for exploration and development work authorized by an approved reclamation permit issued under the Mines Act, being undertaken on a mineral claim in good standing in a recreation area designated under section 23 of the Mineral Tenure Act,
for a use for which, prior to April 1, 1988, no fee was payable, or
if the minister directs that payment is not required.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (4) and (6), the fees payable under this section are in addition to and not instead of any other amount payable by an applicant or permit holder under the Act, this regulation, or another enactment.
No fee listed in Parts 3 and 4 of Schedule K for a park use permit or resource use permit is payable if the permit is issued to a non-profit organization.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 67/94, s. 3.]
The following enactments are prescribed for purposes of section 4 (3) (b) of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulations under the Ecological Reserve Act;
sections 12 and 13 of the Environmental Management Act;
section 9 of the Firearm Act;
Liquor Control and Licensing Act ;
Cannabis Control and Licensing Act ;
Motor Vehicle Act and regulations under that Act;
Off-Road Vehicle Act and regulations under that Act;
sections 2, 4, 5 and 6 of the Trespass Act.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Prohibition of Aircraft Arrivals and Departures and Exceptions

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Fees for Park Use Permits and Resource Use Permits

bcl:schedule.bcl:centertext: Tax imposed under Part IX of the Excise Tax Act (Canada) applies to all fees in this schedule but is not included in the listed amounts.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Part 1 Application Fees for Park Use Permits and Resource Use Permits

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Column 1
Column 2

Commercial recreation, one year or longer term minor/low
impact, non-motorized use; multiple trips

Commercial recreation, less than one year term minor/low
impact, non-motorized use; single or multiple trips

Actual costs based on $50/hour staff time,
with a 2-hour minimum and $250 maximum,

Commercial services, general vendors and client services
including: equipment rentals, food concessions and provision
of access transportation

Commercial recreation, motorized major/high impact: heli-ski
operations, use of tracked vehicles, helicopters to guide ski excursions,
boat tours

Minor ski areas compact/small, minimal use of mechanized lifts,
moderate impact

Major resorts alpine ski facilities with multiple mechanized lifts,
lodges, resorts or tourism developments

Actual costs based on $50/hour staff time or
$3 300, whichever is greater

Communication sites transmission/receiving structures; radio,
microwave, repeater, satellite, cellular phones
Roadways public
Roadways industrial or private access

Rights-of-way (utilities) less than 25 km long including hydro
lines, gas, fibre optics, oil, water

Rights-of-way (utilities) longer than 25 km including hydro
lines, gas, fibre optics, oil, water

Actual costs based on $50/hour staff time or
$1 000, whichever is greater

Non-profit organizations use of private or Crown-owned
structures; with or without adjacent area
Private moorage foreshore facilities; docks, wharves
Aquaculture shellfish, molluscs, finfish
Quarrying rock or aggregate removal
Log handling log storage, log sorts
Alternative power projects includes water and wind power

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Column 1
Column 2

50% of new application fee
Minor amendments to permit
Major amendments to permit

oasis:line.in:em: Types of permits classified according to the use permitted
Fees payable by an individual, group, company or local government for use of Park Act lands
Fees payable by an individual or company for industrial use of Park Act lands

oasis:entry.oasis:line:
Privately-owned structures
The exclusive use of a structure or structures not supplied by the Province
(a)without a defined adjacent area (site only), or
$500 per year and $50 per structure per year
$1000 per year
(b)with a defined adjacent area.
$500 per year and $250 per hectare per year plus $50 per structure per year.

$1 000 per year or $500 per hectare per year plus $100 per structure per year, whichever is greater.
Satellite Facilities
$200 per site per year
Tent/Spike Camp
$100 per site per year
The exclusive use of a structure or structures supplied in whole or in part by the Province, with or without a defined adjacent area.
$500 per year, or, if occupying a defined adjacent area, $25 per m2 of structure per year plus $250 per hectare per year, whichever is greater.
$1000 per year, or, if occupying a defined adjacent area, $50 per m2 of structure per year plus $500 per hectare per year, whichever is greater.
The use of a defined area for a road, chairlift, trail, ski run or ski trail.

Individual or group:
$500 per year or $60 per hectare per year, whichever is greater.
Company or local government:
$500 per year or 2% of gross revenues per year, whichever is greater.
$500 per year or $60 per hectare per year, whichever is greater.

oasis:line.in:em: Rights of way and miscellaneous land use without structures

oasis:entry.oasis:line: The use of a defined area for a powerline, telephone line, pipeline or other service or utility right of way and other miscellaneous land use without structures.

Individual or group:
$60 per hectare per year
Company or local government:
$500 per year or $60 per hectare per year, whichever is greater.
$1000 per year or $60 per hectare per year, whichever is greater.
Item
Column 1
Column 2

oasis:line.in:em:
Types of park use permits and resource use permits
classified according to the use permitted

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Commercial recreation major resorts The use of a defined area to operate alpine ski facilities or large-scale lodges and resorts.
$500 per year and a percentage of gross revenues as identified in the park use permit or resource use permit.

Commercial use/activity
The use of a defined area to carry on, for compensation received or promised, a commercial activity not referred to in any other item of this schedule, whether or not the right to use the area or conduct the activity is exclusive.

oasis:line.in:em: (a)Non-motorized activity and no use of structures

oasis:entry.oasis:line:
For six consecutive months or less,
$125 or $1 per client day, whichever is greater.
For six consecutive months to one year,
$250 or $1 per client day, whichever is greater.

$500 per year or $1 per client day plus
$50 per structure plus, if occupying a defined adjacent area,
$250 per hectare per year, whichever is greater
The use of a defined area to carry on commercial activities in which tracked vehicles, fixed wing planes or helicopters are used to guide or conduct ski excursions.
$1000 per year or $4 per user day, whichever is greater.
The use of a defined area for the grazing of animals.

$100 per year or the total ground rent plus, if the permittee held a licence or permit under the Range Act, the grazing fee that would be payable each year under section 10 of the Range Regulation, B.C. Reg. 199/2000, in respect of the territory and animals to which the permit relates, whichever is greater.
The use of a defined area for the purpose of seeding, raising and harvesting oysters, other molluscs and finfish.
$500 per year or $100 per hectare per year, whichever is greater.
The use and occupancy of a defined area for a television, radio, microwave or other communication structure.
$1000 per year or $500 per hectare per year plus $100 per facility per year, whichever is greater.
The use of a defined area for the purpose of removing sand, gravel, rock or other material.
$1000 per year or $500 per hectare per year plus $100 per facility per year, whichever is greater.

The use, by the holder of a registered trapline under the Wildlife Act, of a territory allocated for trapping purposes and of cabins, without an adjacent area, for purposes incidental to the seasonal operation of a trapline.

Trapping
$100 per year.
Trapping Cabins
$10 per cabin per year to a maximum of $25 per year.

Major Shoot
The lesser of $50 000 and the sum of the following:
(a) $1 500 per day of filming in each park that is a high-value film park;
(b) $750 per day of preparing, wrapping or holding in each park that is a high-value film park;
(c) $400 per day of filming, preparing, wrapping or holding in each park that is not a high-value film park.
Minor Shoot
$100.

oasis:line.in:em: Guide outfitters, transporters and angling guides licensed pursuant to the

oasis:entry.oasis:line: (a)The use, by a guide outfitter, transporter or angling guide, of a territory allocated in conjunction with the activity of a guide outfitter, transporter or angling guide.

For six consecutive months or less,
$125 or $1 per client day, whichever is
greater.
For six consecutive months to one year,
$250 or $1 per client day, whichever is greater.
(b)The exclusive use of a structure or structures not supplied by the Province but used in conjunction with the activity of a guide outfitter, transporter or angling guide:
(i)without a defined adjacent area (site only), or
$500 per year
(ii)with a defined adjacent area.

Base Facilities
$500 per year or $1 per client day plus
$250 per hectare per year plus $50 per
structure per year, whichever is greater.
Satellite Facility
$50 per year
Tent/Spike Camp
$25 per year

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Schedule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: measurements expressed in hectares must be rounded upwards to the next whole hectare and measurements expressed in square metres or cubic metres are rounded upwards to the next whole square metre or cubic metre, and
measurements expressed in square metres of any structure must be based on the outside dimensions including verandahs or porches.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Schedule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: base facility means a facility that is the main location or one of the main locations for a commercial or industrial operation;
defined means an area specified in the park use permit or resource use permit for which the fee is payable;
high-value film park means any of the following parks:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Alice Lake Park;
Brandywine Falls Park;
Coquihalla Canyon Park;
Cultus Lake Park;
Cypress Park;
E. C. Manning Park;
Elk Falls Park, excluding the Elk Falls Protected Area;
Garibaldi Park;
Golden Ears Park;
Goldstream Park;
Gordon Bay Park;
Juan de Fuca Park;
MacMillan Park;
Mount Seymour Park;
Murrin Park;
Peace Arch Park;
Porteau Cove Park;
Rathtrevor Beach Park;
Sasquatch Park;
Shannon Falls Park;
Skaha Bluffs Park;
Stawamus Chief Park, including the Stawamus Chief Protected Area;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: minor shoot means commercial film production with no disturbance of the users or natural resources of a park, conservancy or recreation area;
non-profit organization means a club or association that is a society as defined in the Societies Act or a school board incorporated under the School Act, in which the use or activity undertaken is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of demonstrable benefit to the whole community, and
consistent with the approved objectives of the park, conservancy or recreation area;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: satellite facility means a facility with one permanent structure, excluding pit toilets, that is used for temporary accommodation, storage of supplies or fuel, or as an emergency shelter or an improved helicopter landing site;
structure means any building or permanent improvement constructed, placed or established on Park Act lands, excluding pit toilets;
tent/spike camp means a site with no permanent improvements or structures used on a non-exclusive basis for temporary tenting accommodation or the storage of supplies;
trapping cabin means a cabin used for shelter and for storage of trapping supplies on a periodic but temporary basis in conjunction with the operation of a trapline.

reg:content.reg:provisionsnote: [Provisions relevant to the enactment of this regulation: Park Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 344, s. 29]
